user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 2.1 is: A project shall not contain unreachable code.

</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of calculate_add_nonce:
```c
static bool
calculate_add_nonce (struct MHD_Connection *const connection,
                     uint64_t timestamp,
                     const char *realm,
                     size_t realm_len,
                     struct DigestAlgorithm *da,
                     char *nonce)
{
  struct MHD_Daemon *const daemon = MHD_get_master (connection->daemon);
  struct MHD_NonceNc *nn;
  const size_t nonce_size = NONCE_STD_LEN (digest_get_size (da));
  bool ret;

  mhd_assert (! da->hashing);
  mhd_assert (MAX_DIGEST_NONCE_LENGTH >= nonce_size);
  mhd_assert (0 != nonce_size);

  calculate_nonce (timestamp,
                   connection->rq.http_mthd,
                   connection->rq.method,
                   daemon->digest_auth_random,
                   daemon->digest_auth_rand_size,
                   connection->addr,
                   (size_t) connection->addr_len,
                   connection->rq.url,
                   connection->rq.url_len,
                   connection->rq.headers_received,
                   realm,
                   realm_len,
                   daemon->dauth_bind_type,
                   da,
                   nonce);

#ifdef MHD_DIGEST_HAS_EXT_ERROR
  if (digest_ext_error (da))
    return false;
#endif /* MHD_DIGEST_HAS_EXT_ERROR */

  if (0 == daemon->nonce_nc_size)
    return false;

  /* Sanity check for values */
  mhd_assert (MAX_DIGEST_NONCE_LENGTH == NONCE_STD_LEN (MAX_DIGEST));

  nn = daemon->nnc + get_nonce_nc_idx (daemon->nonce_nc_size,
                                       nonce,
                                       nonce_size);

  MHD_mutex_lock_chk_ (&daemon->nnc_lock);
  if (is_slot_available (nn, timestamp, nonce, nonce_size))
  {
    memcpy (nn->nonce,
            nonce,
            nonce_size);
    nn->nonce[nonce_size] = 0;  /* With terminating zero */
    nn->nc = 0;
    nn->nmask = 0;
    ret = true;
  }
  else
    ret = false;
  MHD_mutex_unlock_chk_ (&daemon->nnc_lock);

  return ret;
}
```
</target_code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation: I have reported fragments that contain unconditional return statements or code whose execution/validity depends on preprocessor configuration or sizing (these are the primary places where unreachable code or code that may be skipped unconditionally could arise). Other parts of the function do not contain unconditional jumps/returns, infinite loops, or constant false/true conditions that would make subsequent code unreachable. The mhd_assert lines are runtime checks (often disabled in production) and do not themselves create unreachable code; the normal if/else around is_slot_available covers both branches with no unreachable statements left after the mutex is locked; and the final return (return ret;) is the normal exit for the function. Therefore those other fragments do not need investigation for Rule 2.1 (unreachable code) based on the presented source alone.
